video.title: The Last of Us Part II (Zero Punctuation)

club to be able to watch these videos a week ahead of all the plebs.
Alright, now we can shit all over The Last of Us 2.

The Last of Us 2, then. Title&#39;s still not accurate &#39;cos
there are quite a lot of people still alive

in the Mumblecore Apocalypse, although in
fairness the main characters seem to be doing

everything they can to rectify this oversight.
Now, don&#39;t get me wrong, viewer; playing the

Last of Us 2 was a pretty miserable experience.
(pause) Kinda sounded like you were going

to say But, there, Yahtzee. Mm? No. It&#39;s really
fucking miserable and depressing and I would

have enjoyed my weekend more had I spent it
teasing out my bum hairs with pliers. I used

to think the Uncharted games rubbed me up
the wrong way because they were too smug and

quippy and didn&#39;t give all the murdering its
due seriousness, but I guess that couldn&#39;t

have been it because Last of Us dialogue is
mostly sad people mumbling very serious things

in between five minute dramatic pauses, so
it must be something else about Naughty Dog

games. Is it that the enemies always pursue
the protagonists far beyond the point where

it makes any sense for them to do so? Probably
not, because that&#39;s only because they hate

the protagonists so much, in which case, hey,
we&#39;ve got something in common, enemies. Let&#39;s

ditch these losers and patrol the local bowling
alley.

Oh it&#39;s a perfectly well made game, even if
it is a stealth action adventure with crafting

and collectibles, which is to say, the same
as every fingerblasting generic triple-A single

player game now, since I can only assume the
corporate games industry finally tracked down

the last creative person in it and replaced
them with an algorithm, but it is pretty good

stealth action. There&#39;s a skin of your teeth
desperate sort of thrill to it, it&#39;s not difficult

to lose the enemy if you do get spotted so
the cockups don&#39;t cascade, the AI is surprisingly

dynamic. They even all have individual names
which they cry out in horror whenever they

find a corpse, a feature that I assume exists
to make the protagonists seem even more like

bastards. Especially when the dudes with adorable
sniffer dogs show up and after you murder

them everyone yells &quot;No! You killed Doctor
Sniffybum! And his dog!&quot; In the non-stealth

action bits, however, gameplay&#39;s a bit of
a slog. Quite a large percentage of it essentially

boils down to &quot;press forward to continue&quot;
and usually the game indicates the direction

in which &quot;forward&quot; lies by having someone
point to the skybox and say &quot;You see that?

That&#39;s where the next plot event is. You see
everything leading up to it? That&#39;s all the

meaningless fucking filler you&#39;re going to
have to slog through to get there.&quot;

No doubt there&#39;ll be at least one infected
hangout. You&#39;ll know you&#39;re there when you

get instakilled by a zombie you weren&#39;t ready
for because all the pushing forward to continue

was putting you to fucking sleep. Actually
there&#39;s a token open world section early on,

perhaps because of algorithms again, but the
side objectives only really provide optional

loot and very little in the way of extra challenge
or story, so it&#39;s only there if you feel like

putting off the rest of the plot. Which you
might, if you hate watching horrible people

take the most irrational course of action
available. Welp, that&#39;s as far as we can go

without spoilers, so only continue watching
if you&#39;ve stopped caring, you aloof disenfranchised

zoomers, you. Here&#39;s the plot. Protagonist
of last game gets murdered by group seeking

revenge for thing protagonist did in last
game, adopted daughter of protagonist goes

to group&#39;s home base to get double backsy
revenge which happens to be in a really shitty

holiday destination, and no, it didn&#39;t escape
me that this is the same plot as Silent Hill

3. Now, Joel in the last game was a basically
relatable gruff hairy dad learning to love

again who made one very questionable decision
at the end.

But Ellie in Last of Us 2 seems to be of a
mind that the best way to commemorate gruff

hairy dad would be to beat his questionable
decision speed record as many times as possible.

And already I hear the same people who gave
me shit about not liking the last game slithering

out from behind the fridge to make the same
argument - you&#39;re not supposed to like or

agree with the characters! It&#39;s complex and
challenging drama! Yeah, thanks Professor,

I got we weren&#39;t supposed to be entirely on
Ellie&#39;s side around the Doctor Sniffybum incident.

But the message is muddled by everyone in
Ellie&#39;s conventionally attractive mumblecore

support group assuring her that revenge is
the tops and totally justified, and the villains&#39;

equivalent act of revenge against Joel for
doing something a lot worse was totally not

justified because they hadn&#39;t had nearly enough
screen time. Which is presumably why, just

as the plot is starting to look like it&#39;s
wrapping up, the game suddenly flashes back

and makes us play as the main villain for
way, way too fucking long, to show that ooh

they have redemptive qualities as well and
from their perspective Ellie is basically
a less eloquent Jason Voorhees.

So we have to slog through more endless hours
of get to the thing in the skybox filler gameplay

before we can have that promised plot resolution,
and none of it&#39;s necessary because it was

already perfectly clear that nobody&#39;s in the
right on all this and the end result is that

I don&#39;t sympathise with anyone. Yahtzee, you
don&#39;t need to sympathise with the characters

for a plot to work. You liked Spec Ops The
Line, and everyone in that game&#39;s a drawstring

shitbag. Can I do a spot of disabusing here?
The kind I always have to do whenever they

put out a David Cage game or anything else
presenting a facade of dramatic depth. The

following things do not make a character deep
or compelling. 1. Getting hurt a lot. Looking

at you, Tomb Raider reboot. 2. Being sad.
3. Doing morally questionable things. And

we might as well tack on 4. Being a member
of a minority, just &#39;cos I&#39;ve already given

up hope for this video&#39;s comment section.
What does matter is that characters at least

be interesting to watch, and these aren&#39;t.
The banter between Ellie and her girlfriend

as they adventure together sizzles like a
flask of slightly tepid water because they&#39;re

too similar, in personality, background and
motivation, to have good chemistry.

But the most important thing is growth. Walker
in Spec Ops The Line slowly becomes a monster

as he&#39;s twisted by the constant backfiring
of his good intentions and that&#39;s why it&#39;s

compelling. Ellie has no character development.
Villain lady does a little bit for stupid

reasons along the lines of suddenly realising
that the enemy faction she&#39;s been genociding

unquestioned for months are also human beings
with families and would rather not be genocided

thanks, but Ellie just sets out to do something
shitty and remains a shitty person. In fact

the game keeps droning on for about two hours
after you think it&#39;s finally ending just to

continue establishing Ellie&#39;s shittiness.
And corporate game dev being what it is, when

I think of the developers almost certainly
being exploited and overworked to make this

miserable game so unnecessarily long, I wince,
viewer. I wince at the pointless suffering.

&#39;Cos you could strip four or five hours of
gameplay out of Last of Us 2 and lose nothing.

Then use the money you saved to make a low
budget platformer on the side about a funny

cartoon dog on a quest to sniff all the butts.
Whose character grows when he realises he

doesn&#39;t have to define himself by sniffing
butts. Bam, compelling plot and we didn&#39;t
even have to retroactively make him a lesbian.
